facts.text: Veeranna had two wives: first wife Atchamma (sons Chimpirayya d.5-5-1945, Pitchayya d.1-9-1905); second wife Seshamma (sons Peda Punnayya died unmarried, China Punnayya).
Veeranna died 2-2-1906. Pitchayya predeceased him leaving widow Raghavamma (plaintiff/appellant).
Alleged adoption: sometime before death, Pitchayya took Venkayya (son of brother Chimpirayya) in adoption.
Alleged partition: in or about 1895, partition of joint family properties between Veeranna and his four sons; Veeranna took 4 acres, rest divided by metes and bounds between four sons.
Venkayya (alleged adopted son) died 24-5-1938 leaving son Subbarao d.28-7-1949.

Chimpirayya executed will dated 14-1-1945 giving properties in equal shares to Subbarao and Kamalamma (daughter of pre-deceased daughter Saraswatamma); directed Raghavamma to manage till grandchildren attain majority.
Chimpirayya died 5-5-1945; Raghavamma allowed Chenchamma (widow of Venkayya) to manage properties.

Raghavamma filed suit on 12-10-1950 in Subordinate Judge, Bapatla for possession of plaint schedule properties (A,B,C,D,D-1,E schedules alleged to be Chimpirayya's); defendants: Chenchamma (D1), Kamalamma (D2 minor), China Punnayya (D3).
D1 denied adoption of Venkayya, denied partition, claimed Chimpirayya died undivided from Subbarao who took by survivorship; denied will validity.
D2 supported plaintiff; D3 denied some allegations, disputed schedules.
Issues: (1) Whether adoption of Venkayya true and valid? (2) Whether Pitchayya and Chimpirayya divided as alleged?
Subordinate Judge dismissed suit holding no proof of adoption or partition.
High Court affirmed findings, rejected plea that will recitals severed status.
Appeal to SC by certificate on questions re will effecting severance.

legal_issues.text: Whether the adoption of Venkayya by Pitchayya was true and valid
Whether Pitchayya and Chimpirayya were divided as alleged by the plaintiff
Whether a will executed by a member of a joint Hindu family effects severance in status by reason of disposition contained therein
Whether recitals in the will constitute an unambiguous declaration of intention to divide, effecting severance
Scope of appeal under certificate under Article 133(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Findings on adoption and partition vitiated by not drawing presumptions for old transactions, ignoring public documents, admissions, conduct of parties
Even assuming no metes and bounds partition, division in status between Chimpirayya and Pitchayya conferring right to bequeath
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law on separation in status

petitioner_arguments.text: Will contains recitals showing Chimpirayya was divided member; recitals constitute unambiguous declaration of intention to divide; no need for communication before death
Chenchamma (guardian) present at will execution, so communication made

respondent_arguments.text: Certificate confined to three questions on will; cannot question adoption/partition findings or raise new points
Concurrent findings of fact on adoption and partition by two courts; SC does not interfere absent exceptional circumstances
Sustain findings on evidence: no proof of adoption/partition; no severance by uncommunicated will
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law requiring communication of intention

court_reasoning.text: Rejects preliminary objection: valid certificate under Art.133 allows full review of facts/law
court_reasoning.key_observation: Terms of certificate do not circumscribe appeal scope

court_reasoning.text: Will not interfere with concurrent findings on adoption/partition: no exceptional circumstances (not shocking conscience, no injustice); evidence supports no adoption (improbable, no formalities, contradictory docs/conduct)
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on plaintiff not discharged; vague oral evidence, suppressed docs, inconsistent descriptions

court_reasoning.text: No partition inter se Chimpirayya/Pitchayya: no deed/date/details, suppressed evidence (lists, pattas), docs show jointness (assessments, mortgages by Chimpirayya/Punnayya excluding Pitchayya branch)
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption of jointness; no proof of separation among coparceners post any prior partial partition

court_reasoning.text: No prior division in status: no unequivocal declaration by Chimpirayya; conflicting docs introduce ambiguity
court_reasoning.key_observation: Severance requires unambiguous declaration manifested to knowledge of affected members

court_reasoning.text: Will does not effect severance: requires communication of intention to other members; uncommunicated declaration ineffective; no knowledge by Chenchamma/Subbarao before Chimpirayya's death
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hindu law texts and PC decisions require manifestation to knowledge of coparceners; relation back doctrine saves vested rights (Subbarao's survivorship)

court_reasoning.text: Even if intention in will, severance dates to manifestation but rights between manifestation and knowledge protected; here no knowledge pre-death
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine of relation back subject to vested rights

holdings.text: No valid adoption of Venkayya by Pitchayya
No partition/division in status between Chimpirayya and Pitchayya
Severance in joint Hindu family requires unequivocal declaration of intention manifested and brought to knowledge of other coparceners; mere uncommunicated will insufficient
No severance by will here as no pre-death knowledge by Subbarao/guardian

statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; scope not limited by terms

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld concurrent findings of lower courts that no adoption or partition proved; held no severance in status by uncommunicated will as intention not brought to knowledge of coparceners before testator's death; appeal dismissed.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs (as per lower courts)

key_quotes.text: "It is settled law that in the case of a joint Hindu family subject to the law of the Mitaksara, a severance of estate is effected by an unequivocal declaration on the part of one of the joint holders of his intention to hold his share separately, even though no actual division takes place."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Restates law on severance by declaration (citing Syed Kasam)

key_quotes.text: "A successful party no doubt can question the maintainability of the appeal on the ground that the certificate was issued by the High Court in contravention of the provisions of Art. 133 of the Constitution, but once the certificate was good, the provisions of Art. 133 did not confine the scope of the appeal to the certificate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects preliminary objection on appeal scope

key_quotes.text: "An uncommunicated declaration is no better than a mere formation or harbouring of an intention to separate. It becomes effective as a declaration only after its communication to the person or persons who would be affected thereby."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on need for communication of intention
